newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian experts barred from freighter crash site.
newsitem.headline: Russian experts barred from freighter crash site.

text.p: Italian authorities have prevented Russian investigators from working at the site where a Russian Antonov-124 freighter crashed near Turin last Tuesday, an aviation official said on Friday.

"Russian experts were denied access to the debris of the aircraft and they could not take pictures or work with documents because the Turin prosecution objected," said an official of the Interstate Aviation Committee who asked not to be named.
He told Reuters that Italian police had removed all documents from the plane.
"Our experts have not seen them yet but time has been lost and it will make the investigation more difficult," the official added.
The head of the Russian team, Mikhail Tereshenko, sent a letter on Friday to Russian aviation organisations and to the Foreign Ministry to ask for their help in the case.
The giant An-124 crashed on Tuesday near Turin airport after its crew failed in their first landing attempt.
Earlier this week a chief executive of Aeroflot -Russian International Airlines, Marshal Evgeny Shaposhnikov, called the crash inexplicable.
"The crew (of the plane) met an inexplicable situation and it is not known why they could not get out of it. All the pilots were very experienced," Shaposhnikov said.

The cargo jet had two crews of six pilots each on board and a further 11 officials from Ayaks cargo company which owned the plane. Aeroflot provided its crews to Ayaks, which owns an additional An-124 freighter but does not have the right to operate it.
The Russian pilot and co-pilot were killed and two villagers died when they were buried in rubble after the plane sliced into the village of San Francesco al Campo on a flight from Moscow.
